Interface QueueADT<E>

All Superinterfaces:
Serializable
All Known Implementing Classes:
MyQueue
public interface QueueADT<E> extends Serializable

  • Method Details

    • QueueADT

      void QueueADT(int i)

      This QueueADT interface is designed as a base for the Queue data structures. To use this interface you will need to implement all methods included.

      Type Parameters:
      E - This is used to hold the type of elements the Queue will utilize

    • enqueue

      E enqueue(E element) throws NullPointerException, FullQueueException
      The enqueue method appends the chosen element to the end of the Queue.
      Parameters:
      add - Element to be appended to this list.
      Returns:
      The element that will be enqueued
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - This exception occurs when the value of element E is null.
      FullQueueException
      IndexOutOfBoundsException - This exception occurs when the value of the index is out of the Queue's bounds.

    • dequeue

      E dequeue() throws NullPointerException, EmptyQueueException
      The dequeue method removes the first element from the queue, moving all other elements forward in the queue.
      Returns:
      This will return the element that was removed from the queue.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - This exception occurs when the value of element E is null.
      EmptyQueueException

    • peek

      E peek() throws NullPointerException, IndexOutOfBoundsException, EmptyQueueException
      The peek method allows viewing the first element in a Queue without making any alterations to the Queue.
      Returns:
      This will return the first element in the Queue
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - This exception occurs when the value of element E is null.
      IndexOutOfBoundsException - This exception occurs when the value of the index is out of the Queue's bounds.
      EmptyQueueException

    • equals

      boolean equals(QueueADT<E> that)
      The equals method compares the values of two elements to determine if they are equal.
      Parameters:
      that - The element that will be compared to
      Returns:
      This will return true if both elements are of equal value, otherwise returns false.

    • iterator

      Iterator<E> iterator()
      This will create a iterator to run travel through the elements of the Queue.
      Returns:
      This will return an iterator to traverse the Queue.

    • toArray

      Object[] toArray()
      This will create an array of objects containing all the elements of the Queue in the identical order.
      Returns:
      This returns an array of objects with the elements in the same order they were in the Queue.

    • toArray

      E[] toArray(E[] copy) throws NullPointerException
      This will create an array of elements containing all the elements of the Queue in the identical order.
      Parameters:
      copy - The element E array that will be used to create the duplicate array.
      Returns:
      This returns an array of elements with the elements in the same order they were in the Queue.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - This exception occurs when the value of element E is null.

    • isFull

      boolean isFull()
      The isFull method is used when a Queue has fixed size. It is used to determine if the number of elements are at the Queue's maximum capacity or not.
      Returns:
      This will return true if the number of elements in the Queue is at the maximum capacity, otherwise returns false.

    • size

      int size()
      The size method is used to view the number of elements in the Queue at the time of access.
      Returns:
      The amount of elements currently in the Queue.

    • isEmpty

      boolean isEmpty()
      The isEmptymethod is used to determine if a Queue does not contain any elements.
      Returns:
      This returns true if there are no elements in the Queue, otherwise the Queue is not empty.

    • dequeueAll

      void dequeueAll()
      The dequeueAll method is used to clear the Queue. Each element is removed from queue in the first-in, first-out sequence.
